comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] They still survive in the Georgian areas of Dublin...

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: My father was born on that day and received the name "Lorenzo" as his third Christian name - no doubt to honour the cardinal!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] Oooh-er, Lorenzo! Could have been a lot worse, I guess...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: As you might imagine, he doesn't use it.  I suppose when you think of all those Irish men with "Mary" as their middle name, it's not that bad!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] My brother hears you!! Damien Mary...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
The Big Enclosed 'Alter' is now in the Grounds of Cappagh Hospital Finglas.
You would not get the same Volume of people nowadays turning up for a Religious Celebration by a Roman Representative...unless they were protesting!!!!!

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: A (late in his life) friend of mine, LtCol Sean Clancy, was one of the officer guard of honour that you can see surrounding and facing the temporary altar - he died in 2006, aged 105. My grandfather-in-law was also at the Congress, as a 10-year-old boy scout on "crowd duty" ... .

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] 105? What a venerable age! We have pictures of the scouts - I think that they all camped out in the Phoenix Park for the duration of the Congress: catalogue.nli.ie/Record/IND_H_2189
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] Thanks! Added your information about Cappagh to our NLI catalogue. Just click on Show more notes...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content:
A venerable age indeed - and a quick mind to the end, which made for a lot of very interesting chats. 
Thanks for the link! The NLI's Eucharistic Congress collection is fascinating. I'll show some of them to my GF-in-law and see if he recognises anything. The devotion on display is remarkable - I think it'll be a very different story when the Congress re-visits Ireland next year.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] Should make for some interesting scenes in Dublin, especially as Bloomsday falls just at the end of it...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Home Rule Rome Rule for all to see.
